Documentation-ception

Running Jekyll Locally

First of all, check out the GitHub Pages guide
This is written with you having read that in mind, but just spelling out things for the slow people (me).
Having installed the prerequisites and cloned the repo, go to the local directory for the repo. Open the terminal there.
To run Jekyll, you need a Gemfile. Create it, such as through `touch Gemfile`, then add `gem 'jekyll'` to add that as a dependency.
The rest of the instructions are clear as is.

Buuuuut for ease of copy pasting >:3
bundle exec jekyll serve
http://localhost:4000
To add new gems, remember to use 'gem install'

Check out the Midnight theme's repo. There's some useful instructions there for locally using themes.

Linking Pages

    Various ways I've tried linking with GitHub Pages after I hadn't used HTML for years. Each entry has a score [0, 1], indicating if it works (and how well, ish)
  • [0 Relative Linking to same repo](StartupProcessCopy.md) I think this got deprecated
  • 0.5 Link to file in the same repo. Raw file
  • 1 Link to readme in different repo. Literally a link to that page (not the GitHub Pages)
  • 1 Hardlinking to another repo. Pulls up the readme (only thing there). Pulls up that repo's index.html otherwise. Make sure the pages source is set in the repo settings.
  • 1 Relative linking to another repo. Same caveats as hardlinking.
  • 0.7 Relative linking to file in same repo.
  • Relative linking to file in same repo. but without the folder indicator
  • 1 Relative linking to file in same repo. but with proper formatting, you stupid bitch
